items.title: Obama’s Second-Term Options on the Environment
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: What Obama can do to cut climate risk and improve the environment in his second term.

items.title: Italy's Oil Leader Is Pursuing Its East African Bet
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: Beginning in 2010, the Italian oil company and a rival, Anadarko Petroleum, made a series of finds in Mozambique that add up to the largest natural gas trove of recent years.

items.title: Renewable Energy Industries Push for New Financing Options
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: With government approval, investment structures more commonly used by the oil, gas and real estate industries could make wind and solar companies more appealing to investors.

items.title: Because Green Goes With Everything
items.author: By Constance Rosenblum
items.abstract: Ron Shiffman has long advocated for buildings that are both resilient and sustainable.

items.title: Energy Department Is the Latest Victim of an Online Attack
items.author: By Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: The attack, which compromised the personal data of several hundred employees, is the latest in a string of major online attacks to surface in the last week.

items.title: For the Love of Carbon
items.author: By Paul Krugman
items.abstract: Building Keystone XL is about creating jobs, Republicans say — but it’s really about creating a richer fossil fuel industry.

items.title: Senate to Debate Keystone XL, Setting Stage for More Energy Battles
items.author: By Coral Davenport
items.abstract: A measure that would force approval of the oil pipeline appears certain to pass, in a preview of clashes to come between President Obama and the new Republican Congress.

items.title: Green-Energy Inspiration Off the Coast of Denmark
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: Residents of islands off Maine’s coast seek to draw on the experiences of the Danish island Samso in an effort to explore alternative sources of light and heat.

items.title: A Climate Hawk Separates Energy Thought Experiments from Road Maps
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: A progressive “climate hawk” says simplified road maps for solving the climate challenge are counterproductive.

items.title: Federal Construction Projects Must Plan for Flood Risks From Climate Change
items.author: By Coral Davenport
items.abstract: President Obama issued an executive order requiring that all federally funded construction projects take into account the flood risks linked to global warming.

items.title: Senate Begins Debate on Comprehensive Bipartisan Energy Bill
items.author: By Coral Davenport
items.abstract: The proposed energy legislation focuses on protecting and improving the power grid and updating the oil and gas infrastructure.

items.title: Clean Energy Revolution?
items.abstract: A policy specialist writes that a real revolution will take more than “modest policy changes.”

items.title: Oil Price Drop May Add to Tax Bills for Popular Energy Investments
items.author: By Gretchen Morgenson
items.abstract: Devastation in the oil patch has caused great losses for investors in master limited partnerships, and in some cases also increased their tax burden.

items.title: In Zika Epidemic, a Warning on Climate Change
items.author: By Justin Gillis
items.abstract: In the coming decades, global warming is likely to increase the range and speed the life cycle of the particular mosquitoes carrying viruses like Zika.

items.title: Bill Gates, the ‘Impatient Optimist,’ Lays Out his Clean-Energy Innovation Agenda
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Bill Gates discusses the investment and research efforts he’s pursuing to energize societies without overheating the climate.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: With a Major Oil Discovery, Guyana Is Poised to Become a Top Producer
items.author: By Clifford Krauss
items.abstract: Exxon Mobil and Hess may soon confirm that the sea floor beneath the South American country’s coastal waters contains one of the richest energy discoveries in decades.

items.title: Li Ka-shing Sweetens Deal for Australian Energy Company
items.author: By Neil Gough
items.abstract: Companies controlled by Mr. Li, Hong Kong’s richest man, announced a deal for the Duet Group worth about $5.5 billion, up slightly from a previous offer last month.

items.title: Offshore Wind Moves Into Energy’s Mainstream
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: Offshore wind projects are luring big-name investors who are attracted to strong returns and declining costs.

items.title: Oroville Is a Warning for California Dams, as Climate Change Adds Stress
items.author: By Adam Nagourney and Henry Fountain
items.abstract: The state’s water infrastructure is suffering from age and stress, and older dams may not be designed to deal with severe weather patterns brought by global warming.

items.title: Solar Experiment Lets Neighbors Trade Energy Among Themselves
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: Dozens of homes and businesses in Brooklyn have been wired into a microgrid, which allows members to exchange excess-electricity credits.

items.title: There Is Nothing Virtual About Bitcoin’s Energy Appetite
items.author: By Nathaniel Popper
items.abstract: Creating a single token requires as much electricity as two years’ worth of consumption by an average American home. Some enthusiasts believe that’s a problem.

items.title: The Energy Solution Latin America Needs
items.author: By Lisa Viscidi and Ariel Yépez
items.abstract: For a more robust power system, the region needs multicountry investments and a better regulatory framework.

items.title: Trump’s Infrastructure Plan May Ignore Climate Change. It Could Be Costly.
items.author: By Coral Davenport
items.abstract: President Trump wants to spend $1.5 trillion on rebuilding roads and bridges, but experts say failing to account for climate change will add to costs.

items.title: ‘I’m Just More Afraid of Climate Change Than I Am of Prison’
items.author: By Michelle Nijhuis
items.abstract: How a group of five activists called the Valve Turners decided to fight global warming by doing whatever it takes.

items.title: Geothermal Energy Grows in Kenya
items.author: By Amy Yee
items.abstract: Rapid expansion of geothermal energy generation has helped increase electrical access in Kenya. But the country faces challenges in making electricity widely available.

items.title: Climate Change’s Giant Impact on the Economy: 4 Key Issues
items.author: By Neil Irwin
items.abstract: Many of the big economic questions in coming decades will come down to just how extreme the weather will be, and how to value the future versus the present.

items.title: A Sensible Climate Change Solution, Borrowed From Sweden
items.author: By Richard Rhodes
items.abstract: In “A Bright Future,” Joshua S. Goldstein and Staffan A. Qvist look to Europe for examples of how nuclear energy can help solve the global warming crisis.
keywords: A Bright Future: How Some Countries Have Solved Climate Change and the Rest Can Follow (Book)

items.title: Liberal Democrats Formally Call for a ‘Green New Deal,’ Giving Substance to a Rallying Cry
items.author: By Lisa Friedman and Glenn Thrush
items.abstract: House Democrats introduced a resolution calling for a sweeping environmental and economic mobilization that would make the United States carbon neutral by 2030.

items.title: One Cheer for the Green New Deal
items.author: By Ross Douthat
items.abstract: At least our future socialist overlords aren’t thinking small.
keywords: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

items.title: Trump Pushes Iraq to Stop Buying Energy From Iran
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: The push by American officials to get Iraq to comply with Iran sanctions could lead to more mass protests and political instability in the electricity-starved country.

items.title: Trump Rule Would Exclude Climate Change in Infrastructure Planning
items.author: By Lisa Friedman
items.abstract: The  administration will propose that federal agencies be allowed to disregard climate change when  assessing the environmental effects of  major  projects.

items.title: To Fight Climate Change, One City May Ban Heating Homes With Natural Gas
items.author: By Mike Baker
items.abstract: Seeking to do their part to avert climate change, dozens of cities are exploring ways to limit natural gas heating in new homes. One city may also require existing homeowners to make a switch.

items.title: Marine Labs on the Water’s Edge Are Threatened by Climate Change
items.author: By John Schwartz and Bryan Tarnowski
items.abstract: A marine lab built to withstand hurricanes faces a slower menace: climate change. Problems arising wherever science operates at the shifting border of soil and sea.

items.title: We Can’t Slow Climate Change Without the Energy Companies
items.author: By Ted Halstead
items.abstract: Bigger and faster emissions reductions are possible if environmentalists and industry work together.

items.title: How to Stop Freaking Out and Tackle Climate Change
items.author: By Emma Marris
items.abstract: Here’s a five-step plan to deal with the stress and become part of the solution.

items.title: Let’s Work With Latin America to Fight Climate Change
items.author: By Lisa Viscidi
items.abstract: The Biden administration should support clean energy investments and environmental protections in the region.

items.title: Mountains, Ice and Climate Change: A Recipe for Disasters
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Shrinking and thinning of glaciers is one of the most documented signs of global warming caused by rising levels of greenhouse gases.

items.title: A Glimpse of America’s Future: Climate Change Means Trouble for Power Grids
items.author: By Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Systems are designed to handle spikes in demand, but the wild and unpredictable weather linked to global warming will very likely push grids beyond their limits.

items.title: How Texas’ Drive for Energy Independence Set It Up for Disaster
items.author: By Clifford Krauss, Manny Fernandez, Ivan Penn and Rick Rojas
items.abstract: Texas has refused to join interstate electrical grids and railed against energy regulation. Now it’s having to answer to millions of residents who were left without power in last week’s snowstorm.

items.title: Why Texas Republicans Fear the Green New Deal
items.author: By Naomi Klein
items.abstract: Small government is no match for a crisis born of the state’s twin addictions to market fixes and fossil fuels.

items.title: Hochul Vows to Lift Economy, Lure Health Workers and Add a Transit Link
items.author: By Mihir Zaveri
items.abstract: The proposals, released as part of Ms. Hochul’s first State of the State address, reflected her priorities as she prepares to run for a full term as governor.
keywords: New York City Environmental Justice Alliance

items.title: Here’s How Climate Change and Covid Are Transforming Skiing
items.author: By Lauren Jackson
items.abstract: There’s less snow and stricter rules, but skiers are adjusting in surprising ways.

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.author: By Michael Kolomatsky
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: A North Sea Auction Produces Big Plans for Scottish Wind Farms
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: Oil giants like BP and Shell propose to spend billions on renewable energy, bolstering Scotland’s efforts to move away from an economy based on fossil fuel.

items.title: Conflict and Climate Change Ravage Syria’s Agricultural Heartland
items.author: By Jane Arraf
items.abstract: Drought and a decade of war have brought failing crops and poverty to a region once known as Syria’s breadbasket. Even the bread has changed.
keywords: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

items.title: How Climate Change Is Shaping California’s Winter Storms
items.author: By Raymond Zhong
items.abstract: So far, the downpours are largely in line with past storms, an official said. But their quick pace is testing the limits of the state’s infrastructure.

items.title: Eurozone Inflation Eases on Lower Energy Prices
items.author: By Patricia Cohen
items.abstract: The rate of price increases in countries using the euro slowed to 9.2 percent in December, down from 10.1 percent a month earlier.

items.title: A Deal to Help South Africa Is a Breakthrough for the World
items.author: By The Editorial Board
items.abstract: A plan to promote the shift to renewable energy could lead to real progress on climate change.

items.title: What Exxon Knew, but Concealed, About Climate Change
items.abstract: Readers discuss a new study showing it knew the dangers for decades. Also: The U.S. Embassy in Israel; the debt limit; guns on movie sets; election deniers.

items.title: Golf Course or Housing? A Patch of Green Divides Hong Kong.
items.author: By Joy Dong
items.abstract: The dispute over one of the city’s golf clubs exposes rare political friction for the elite in the new Hong Kong, where the establishment is torn between defending wealth and following Beijing’s wishes.
